In First Step Towards Setting Up Space Station, ISRO To Conduct Space-Docking Test In 2020

After Chandrayaan-2 and Vikram lander's fateful journey, ISRO scientists are now channeling their energy towards a bigger project.

The upcoming project is a space-docking experiment called Spadex and reports state that it's a 'building-block' process of setting up India's very own space station.

Twitter

Docking refers to connecting of two flying objects in space, either to transfer men or material from one to the other, or two join two structures to make a bigger one.

ISRO chairman K Sivan told TOI, "We are going to conduct a docking experiment next year in which two experimental modules will be sent to space (on board a PSLV rocket) and the two will be made to dock with each other in space.”

Mastering this extremely difficult technology is crucial for the operations of an Indian space station; setting up a lab in space means astronauts would need to be ferried from Earth to the space station and back.

How will this work?

The process is complex as it involves controlling the speeds of the two satellites and bringing them together so that they can dock and become a larger structure, says Sivan.

The satellites flying in space at incredible velocities, of the order of 10km a second. When they are a few kilometres away, they communicate with each other and the one in front slows down in order that the follower comes close.

When they are close enough, onboard cameras switch on and guided by camera, one latches on to the other and the two become a larger structure. This can be achieved only if the vehicle also carries the astronauts can dock with the space station.

This mission will only be carried out after after the human spaceflight programme or Gaganyaan mission launches December 2021. Docking will be a key capability in future space operations and ISRO’s first step in that direction –SPADEX—will happen next year.
